title: David's Kindness to Mephibosheth
shortSummary: This chapter recounts King David’s gracious act of kindness toward Mephibosheth, the disabled son of Jonathan and grandson of Saul. Demonstrating faithfulness to his covenant with Jonathan, David restores Mephibosheth’s inheritance and honors him by inviting him to eat at the king’s table continually, illustrating God’s mercy and covenant faithfulness.
timeline: c. 1010 BC - Reign of King David in Israel

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who seeks to show kindness to Jonathan’s family in faithfulness to his covenant.

keyCharacters.name: Mephibosheth
keyCharacters.description: Son of Jonathan and grandson of Saul, lame in both feet, who receives David’s kindness and restoration.

keyCharacters.name: Ziba
keyCharacters.description: A servant of Saul’s house who informs David about Mephibosheth and manages the land for him.

keyCharacters.name: Jonathan
keyCharacters.description: Son of Saul and close friend of David, whose covenant relationship prompts David’s kindness.

definitions.definition: In this context, it refers to loyal love and covenant faithfulness demonstrated through generous and gracious actions.
Physically disabled or crippled, referring here to Mephibosheth’s inability to walk properly due to an injury.
An expression meaning to be honored as a member of the royal household, sharing in the king’s provision and fellowship.
The family and descendants of King Saul, Israel’s first king, whose lineage is significant for David’s political and covenantal considerations.

outline.heading: David Seeks Survivors of Saul’s House
outline.description: David inquires if any descendants of Saul remain to show kindness for Jonathan’s sake, leading to the discovery of Mephibosheth living in Lodebar.

outline.heading: Mephibosheth Brought to David
outline.description: Mephibosheth humbly approaches David, who reassures him and promises to restore his inheritance and honor him at the king’s table.

outline.heading: Restoration of Saul’s Inheritance
outline.description: David commands Ziba to manage the land for Mephibosheth’s benefit, ensuring his provision while Mephibosheth enjoys a privileged place at the royal table.

outline.heading: Mephibosheth’s Life in Jerusalem
outline.description: Mephibosheth lives in Jerusalem, eating continually at the king’s table despite his disability, symbolizing David’s covenant loyalty and God’s grace.

application: Demonstrate faithfulness by honoring commitments and showing kindness to others, especially in keeping promises rooted in covenant relationships.
Trust God’s providence and grace even in physical or social limitations, as seen in Mephibosheth’s honored place despite his disability.
Practice humility and gratitude when receiving God’s blessings and the kindness of others, recognizing our unworthiness apart from grace.
Serve others by providing for their needs and advocating on their behalf, reflecting Christ’s love and mercy in practical ways.

keyVerses.text: And David said unto him, Fear not: for I will surely shew thee kindness for Jonathan thy father's sake, and will restore thee all the land of Saul thy father; and thou shalt eat bread at my table continually.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights David’s covenant faithfulness and the gracious restoration extended to Mephibosheth, symbolizing God’s mercy toward His people.

keyVerses.text: So Mephibosheth dwelt in Jerusalem: for he did eat continually at the king's table; and was lame on both his feet.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes God’s grace that honors and sustains even those with physical disabilities, showing inclusion in the blessings of the kingdom.

keyVerses.text: And David said, Is there yet any that is left of the house of Saul, that I may shew him kindness for Jonathan's sake?
keyVerses.significance: David’s initial inquiry reveals his desire to act in loyal love, setting the tone for the chapter’s message of covenant loyalty and mercy.
